US MARKET WRAP 17 MAY 2019: US/Canada/Mexico agree to lift tariffs; US/China talks said to be influx
content:
* SNAPSHOT: Equities mixed, Dollar up, Treasuries flat, Crude lower.

* REAR VIEW: US/Canada/Mexico agree to lift tariffs, US/China talks said to be “in flux”, Strong Michigan data, hawkish China trade rhetoric, cross-party Brexit talks collapse, Iran says US a short missile range away, US President Trump reportedly doesn’t want war

* COMING UP ON MONDAY: JMMC Meeting (Sun) Data: JN GDP, Speakers: ECB’s Praet, Fed’s Harker, Clarida, Williams, BoE’s Broadbent, Earnings: Ryanair, Telecom Italia

* NEXT WEEK: TUE: RBA mins, US/Japan trade talks, WED: FOMC mins, Japan trade balance, UK CPI, THU: ECB mins, SARB, EZ flash PMI, German Ifo, FRI: Japan CPI, US durable goods, UK retail sales, Trump to visit Japan, SUN: European Parliamentary Election Results

* RANSQUAWK WEEK IN FOCUS; week commencing 20 May 2019, to download the report, please click here.

* US CHINA TRADE:The Chinese have overnight suggested (via a WeChat post that was also carried later in Xinhua) that US officials' visit to Beijing would be pointless unless the US changes its approach and shows sincerity. China also reiterated its previous demand that the US remove all tariffs, ensure any quotas to buy US goods are achievable and based on demand, and any text agreement would need to be balanced - given that national pride seems to be a driving factor in China's stance, this would imply that it wants any enforcement mechanism to be based on regulatory principles, not a change to China's constitutional law. China also said that "if anyone thinks the Chinese side is just bluffing, that will be the most significant misjudgement since Korean War." A spokesperson for China also said that it would "study the possible impact of US tariffs on the Chinese economy, and roll out responsive measures when necessary," implying that further retaliatory action and/or China stimulus may be on the cards. In wake of China's hawkish comments, analysts have said that it implies that it would be difficult to reach a trade deal, and that Beijing seems ready for a protracted dispute. Rabobank says this does not bode well for EM assets. "The widening gap between USDCNY and the MSCI EM FX index is an ominous signal that the EM currencies are likely to come under stronger selling pressure to catch up with the falling yuan." Comments later from the US Soybean Export Council suggested that the US will likely lose market share in China permanently the longer the tension drags, and China is now unlikely to return to buying record US soybean volume even if a deal is reached. China's Global Times said China will certainly retaliate to the barbaric suppression of Huawei and that this is the unanimous attitude of officials and the Chinese people. Pessimism regarding the state of talks took a further turn for the worse as CNBC reported that trade talks between the US and China were “in flux”.

* US/CANADA & MEXICO TRADE: The US came to an agreement with Canada and Mexico to remove tariffs on steel and aluminium imports within 48 hours, with the deal reportedly not involving any quotas. In return, both Canada and Mexico will remove retaliatory tariffs, duties which had been a barrier to the passage of the USMCA. The countries also announced that they would drop all pending litigation in the WTO related to tariffs, set up measures to prevent the import of unfairly subsidised aluminium or steel, prevent the transhipment of aluminium and steel made outside of Canada, US or Mexico and made an agreed-upon process for monitoring steel and aluminium trade between the three countries.

* GEOPOLITICAL: Iranian Revolutionary Guard Deputy Commander said earlier on Friday that Iran’s short-range missiles can reach the US fleet in the Persian Gulf, by no means a constructive comment for those looking for a diplomatic resolution to the tensions in the region. In the US’ (public) efforts to de-escalate the situation, an administration official said that “the US is sitting by the phone” but have not yet heard anything from Iran. Trump reiterated his stance that he does not want a war with Iran, as reports had suggested earlier in the week, but there were also reports that he would use the military if required. Furthermore, following earlier reports Iran was acting on beliefs that the US would attack, a US official denied that Iran is reacting to US provocations.

* BREXIT: Cross-party talks officially collapsed on Friday, with Labour sources reporting that there is no point in doing a deal with a government that is about to collapse, whilst a government spokesperson commented that it was clear a deal between the two parties was never going to happen. A leaked document revealed that the government intends to hold indicative votes on Brexit next week, but Labour sources soon labelled the indicative vote process “dead on arrival” and that they would not cooperate with the government. Following the collapse of the talks, UK PM May is facing renewed calls from conservative MPs to step down. Boris Johnson remains the bookies favourite to succeed her.

* ECB: ECB's Visco said that monetary policy can rely on a wide range of tools to support an economy, and the ECB stand ready to fulfil its mandate if necessary, before adding that it is mistake to believe that monetary policy would be disarmed if the Euro Area falls into a recession leading to deflation. ECB's Weidmann (Hawk) blamed companies’ savings for driving current account imbalance.

* UNI. OF MICHIGAN SENTIMENT: Headline sentiment rose by more than expected, to 102.4 from 97.2, recovering all of the losses seen in Q4, and ising to a 15-year high. "Almost all the increase was in the expectations component, which jumped by 8.6 points, even more than implied by the TIPPOnline index released a couple weeks ago," Pantheon says, "the current conditions index, by contrast, tends to be driven by movements in jobless claims, which are noisy but essentially trendless, so the index rose a trivial 0.1 points." Pantheon notes that in the past, expectations at their May level would be consistent with growth in real spending in excess of 5%, "but that's twice the rate of growth of real after-tax incomes, so it isn't going to happen," the consultancy says. "Still, such high confidence ought to make investors fretting over the soft retail sales number think twice." Pantheon is convinced that spending is just transitioning to a sustainable rate of growth after the two-quarter spike triggered by last year’s tax cuts. "The reversal of the Q4 drop in gas prices is a short-term drag too, but the underlying fundamentals for consumers are very sound, and we expect real consumption growth to trend at about 2.5-to-3% over the next few quarters."

* WTI (M9) SETTLES 0.11 LOWER 62.76/BBL, BRENT (N9) SETTLES 0.41 LOWER AT 72.21/BBL. The crude complex traded on the front foot in earlier Friday trade before peaking and reversing course going into the US session. Fresh news overnight from the Middle East was a comment from an Iranian official saying that Iran’s short-range missiles could reach US warships in the Persian Gulf, which gave bulls some firepower over “stoked fears of a supply disruption in what is the epicentre of world oil supply,” PVM’s analysts encapsulated. However, ahead of the OPEC+ JMMC meeting this weekend, reports on Friday suggested that the oil cartel are mulling a production increase (walking back on the existing supply cut pact), with the sources stating that members are satisfied with oil prices around the USD 70/barrel level. From the time the report hit newswires the market subsequently headed lower through till settlement; a stronger dollar on the day also assisted crude’s trajectory lower to conclude the week not far from where it started. The Baker Hughes weekly rig count recorded US oil rigs down 3 at 802, US nat gas rigs up 2 at 185, with total US rigs down 1 at 987.

* S&P 500 -0.6% at 2859, NASDAQ-10 -1% at 7504, Dow Jones  -0.4% at 25763, SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary -0.8, Consumer Staples -0.2%, S&P 500 Energy -1.1%, S&P 500 Financials -0.6%, Health Care -0.2%, Industrials  -1.1%, Information Technology  -0.8%, Materials  -0.5%, Telecommunication Services  -0.5%, Utilities  0.5%.

* STOCK SPECFICS: Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) opened lower, under pressure after the emergence of news that the drug maker was under FBI investigation over corruption concerns in Brazil. Microsoft (MSFT) was under pressure despite the news that the technology co and Sony (SNE), have struck a deal to form a partnership on video game streaming, where Sony will use Microsoft’s Azure cloud service for its own PlayStation streaming service. Tesla (TSLA) shares were under pressure premarket after CEO Musk announced new cost-cutting efforts following losses in the most recent quarter and news also emerged that the electric automaker will also scale back its plans for autopilot in Europe in wake of regulatory changes. Applied Materials (AMAT) caught a bid after the chipmaker reported strong earnings, beating on both top and bottom lines whilst also raising guidance. Baidu (BIDU) sunk after the technology co lowered its Q3 profit guidance and missed bottom line earning expectations. Nvidia (NVDA) moved higher after the chipmaker reported earnings that beat on top and bottom lines, whilst also rising guidance for Q2, despite the CFO citing difficult outlook going forward. Deere & Co (DE) shares sunk after the manufacturer reported a miss on profit expectations and revised FY19 revenue guidance lower, seeing further downside as the co announced that H2 shipments could be down “in the 20% range”. Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) moved higher after the technology maker confirmed its plans to purchase Cray Inc (CRAY), as the firm seeks to become more competitive in the supercomputer space. Under Armour (UA, UAA) jumped higher after receiving an upgrade from JPM, the investment group citing confidence in the brands direction. Starbucks (SBUX) moved higher with the market, unaffected by the prospect of potential future rival Luckin’ Coffee Inc (LK) first day as a publicly traded company. Wynn (WYNN) and MGM Resorts (MGM) saw some positive ticks after reports emerged that the two were in talks for a potential sale of their Encore Boston Harbour, but ultimately finished lower.

* US T-Note futures settle 2 ticks higher at 124-15+: Treasury yields were lower, and the curve flattened a touch on Friday, after hawkish trade rhetoric out of China. Decent University of Michigan data brought the complex off highs in the US afternoon, and there was further downside on reports that the US would drop metals tariffs on Canadian and Mexican steel and aluminium.

* RANSQUAWK CENTRAL BANK WEEKLY BRIEFING: 17 May 2019, PREVIEWING FOMC mins, ECB mins, SARB, REVIEWING RBA, Banxico, BCB. To download the report, please click here.

* DAILY FX WRAP:

CNH continued its march towards 7 vs USD, as the Chinese press called into question the point of a US visit to Beijing last night. Upside was capped by reports that the PBoC is willing to intervene to protect the 7 level. Conversely, USD drifted higher, seeing further upside in wake of strong US Michigan data. EUR drifted lower, with comments from PM Conte assuring Italian fiscal responsibility doing little to lift sentiment; EURUSD languishing just above 1.1160. JPY finished the session fairly flat, gaining momentum overnight as China’s state media upped the ante, before paring gains as US stocks staged a minor recovery. CAD and MXN jumped as news emerged that the two countries and the US were progressing on the USMCA and nearing a deal to lift metal tariffs, with the Loonie also buoyed by comments from BoC Governor Poloz. The antipodeans, AUD & NZD moved lower, largely mirroring CNH. TRY is flat after choppy action, where a US announcement to end the preferential treatment of Turkey under its Generalised System of Preferences triggered some selling, before reports emerged that Turkey would introduce a bill to prevent the CBRT from boosting Turkish Treasury reserves, leading to a modest recovery. BRL continued to lose ground vs USD since losing the 4.000 level, in wake of this week’s slew of growth warnings.

* WEEKLY FX WRAP - USD: The Dollar has been a broad winner this week as already strained trade relations between the US and China following the end of official talks turned even more sour after tit-for-tat tariff announcements and an ensuing exchange of accusations over which side is to blame for the failure to reach a deal. On that note, the latest verbal tirade came from Beijing blaming Washington for backtracking on pledges and raising the level of aggression via sanctions against Huawei and ZTE. The DXY has made a solid recovery from near 97.000 lows to just a fraction shy of 98.000 with independent momentum coming from some bullish data and survey news, like housing, weekly claims, NY and Philly Fed manufacturing, plus Michigan sentiment in contrast to disappointing retail sales and ip.

* GBP: It’s been a rough week for the Pound as Brexit talks between the Conservative and Labour Parties continued to no avail, with both sides conceding that efforts to cross red lines and compromise on key issues have been exhausted. Meanwhile, UK PM May faced another 1922 ultimatum and this time did not emerge from a meeting with the Tory back-benchers unscathed as she yielded to pressure on a timeframe for her departure and the race is now on to find a new leader. Cable has slumped from circa 1.3040 at best and 1.3000 at the start of the week to a 1.2733 base, while Eur/Gbp has rallied to 0.8766 from 0.8624 at one stage vs 0.8748 at ‘open’ even though the single currency has suffered its own travails.

* EUR: The single currency has also succumbed to the broad Greenback revival from lows posted in wake of the aforementioned weak US data and the initial knee-jerk when China retaliated with tariffs and by halting US agricultural purchases. However, the Euro also suffered from Italian budget-related grounds as Deputy PM Salvini in particular continued to rail against EU budget rules and pledged to tear them up in the event that his Party performs well in the upcoming EU Parliament elections. His protestations offset more encouraging Eurozone data in the form of Q1 GDP and an upward revision to core inflation to leave Eur/Usd rooted near the base of its 1.1265-1158 weekly range and only deriving fleeting respite from confirmation that the US will hold off on EU/Japanese auto tariffs for 6 months pending further discussions and ultimately or hopefully an accord.

* CAD/AUD/NZD: The Loonie, Aussie and Kiwi are all heading for hefty losses vs their US counterpart, with Usd/Cad nearer the top of a 1.3514-1.3398 band, but fading ahead of strong resistance at 1.3524 (April high within a few pips of a Fib) and on reports of a breakthrough in tariff talks between Canada and the US that could culminate in an announcement as soon as later today. However, Aud/Usd and Nzd/Usd are both mired near the lows of their 0.7005-0.6873 and 0.6605-0.6525 respective parameters with the former undermined by soft jobs data, on balance, that has lowered the bar for a June RBA ease, and the latter down in sympathy along with the overarching ramp up in US-China/global trade tensions. Next up for the Aud, the weekend election and for a full preview of the looming vote see the Ransquawk Research Suite.

* JPY/CHF: The relative G10 outperformers and bucking broader trends, albeit selectively, as the Yen resisted most of the Usd’s advances and fluctuations in risk sentiment to hold within 110.04-109.03 confines, and did especially well against other majors on a cross bases, like Sterling, as Gbp/Jpy triggered stops on a break of 140.00. Conversely, the Franc looks all set close out the week down vs the Buck and sub-1.0100 vs 1.0050 at the other extreme, but appreciated vs the Euro between 1.1374-1.1263 boundaries on the fiscal posturing from Rome noted above.

* EM: Mostly risk-off positioning bar general recoveries on Tuesday and Thursday has hit regional currencies this week, but the Rand, Real and Lira have also been subject to negative ratings assessments if not formal reviews or downgrades from the agencies. Meanwhile, Turkey has also deployed more measures to support the Try, like a tax on FX transactions, only have limited impact amidst the wider economic and political problems and with some external support via the US cutting steel levies, but removing preferential status on metals overall. Elsewhere, the Cny and Cnh both remained weak as the PBoC raised mid-point fixings and despite reports that 7.0000 vs the Usd in on shore terms will be defended.

subject: PRIMER: OPEC-Non-OPEC Ministerial Monitoring Committee (JMMC) to meet on 19/May at 1400BST/0800CDT
analysis_details: The Joint OPEC-Non-OPEC Ministerial Monitoring Committee (JMMC) are to convene on May 19th in Jeddah, Saudi Arabia at 1400BST/0800CDT, with a press conference scheduled at 1900BST/1300CDT, although the presser tends to be delayed. The meeting will be co-chaired by Saudi Arabia and Russia and will include other major oil producers including Iraq, the United Arab Emirates, Kuwait, Nigeria and Kazakhstan. Markets will be focused on the meeting, despite the absence of many members, given its influence on OPEC/OPEC+ meetings on June 25/26 where the oil producers are to decide on whether to extend the global supply deal. The conversation is likely to be dominated by geopolitics and the situation surrounding Iran (who will not partake in the meeting this weekend) amid the US sanctions on the country alongside the expiry of Iranian oil waivers. Saudi Energy Minister Al-Falih has already noted that the Kingdom is ready to meet consumer demands and replace Iranian oil, but Saudi will not voluntarily exceed oil production levels set in the global deal. Some desks remind us that shifting from restraining supply to boosting is not easy, especially since there is still little clarity on how far Iranian output will ultimately fall (latest calculations suggest they are now running at a clip of 500k BPD, from about 1mln BPD prior to the US removing sanctions waivers). Citi notes that Saudi will be reluctant to repeat last years’ experience, after Riyadh boosted output to record highs after the US promised to cut off Iranian oil supply, which ended up with eight countries receiving waivers and a 35% decline in oil prices in Q4 2018. There may be some discussion of Russia's compliance with the deal, though it has recently come in line with quotas. All-in-all, markets will be reacting to any hints of a supply curb extension or concerns regarding global supply, although no firm decisions will be made at this meeting given that not all OPEC/OPEC+ members will be present.

subject: Talking Crude: A short missile away from war
content:
• A risk-off sentiment is gripping markets, spurred by reports from China that it increasingly sees no interest in continuing trade talks; however, crude is bucking the trend, catching a bid from renewed geopolitical risk whilst brushing off demand concerns.
  • An Iranian official on Friday said that even short-range missiles could reach US warships in the Persian Gulf, a step in the wrong direction for the diplomacy President Trump is looking for. News overnight also suggested that the US government received intelligence that Iran believed the US was planning an attack on Iran, hence the preparation for conflict out of Tehran. Although Trump is opposed to conflict, analysts point out that it is not hard to see the situation spiraling out of his control. With the Saudis growing more agitated with Iran, claiming it is using the Houthis as a proxy to attack it, on top of Iran instructing its Iraqi militias to prepare for a proxy war, the growing US forces in the region could soon find themselves under attack, regardless of Trump’s or the hawks in his administration’s wishes.
  • Despite the risk of war in the oil capital of the world, crude markets have concluded the week only modestly higher, with short term demand concerns from China overshadowing. UBS' Daniel Ellis notes, “I wouldn’t rule out a move towards USD 80/barrel if tensions in the Middle East continue to escalate beyond the point at which China and the US come to some form of agreement.” The market is also arguably tentative on letting prices run with the OPEC+ JMMC meeting occurring over the weekend. Although no formal decisions on production cuts will be made, there is likely to be headline risk from comments suggesting members' stance on the continuation or discontinuation of the current supply pact.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 17th May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Major European indices [Euro Stoxx 50 -0.5%] are subdued following from a mixed Asia session, with sentiment afflicted by reports that China potentially has no current interest in the continuation of US talks
  • Opposition Labour Leader Corbyn confirms that cross-party Brexit talks have gone as far as they can
  • Looking ahead, highlights include US University of Michigan Sentiment, Fed's Clarida & Williams, ECB's de Guindos

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region took impetus from the positive performance on Wall St, where all major indices notched a 3rd consecutive win streak with risk sentiment underpinned by encouraging earnings from Walmart and Cisco. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.9%) traded positive with Australia led by continued strength in tech and amid the growing list of calls for a rate cut next month including notorious RBA watcher McCrann, while Japanese exporters were buoyed by recent favourable currency moves and as Sony shares surged over 10% after the announcement of a JPY 200bln share buyback. Hang Seng (-1.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (-2.5%) were pressured after a lack of PBoC reverse repo operations throughout the week resulted to net weekly drain of CNY 50bln. In addition, China cancelled orders of 3247 tons of pork from US which was the largest cancellation in more than a year and was seen to be another fallout of the ongoing US-China trade dispute, while commentary in Chinese state media suggested China may have no interest in resuming trade discussions with the US for now. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid the upbeat risk tone in Japan and on spill-over selling from the bear flattening stateside, while the BoJ’s Rinban announcement was for a reserved JPY 200bln of long to super-long JGBs.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 50bln vs. last week's CNY 50bln net injection. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8859 (Prev. 6.8688)

China state media commentary said China may have no interest in continuing trade talks with the US for now and sees little sincerity in President Trump's approach. In related news, the NDRC said trade friction impact on Chinese economy is controllable, while it added that China is to study impact of tariffs and prop up growth when required.

BoJ Governor Kuroda said low rates must be maintained for a long period to achieve the price goal and that forward guidance is the framework in which BoJ will decide policy based on data and information available at the time. Furthermore, Kuroda said there is a good chance BoJ will keep current low rates past Spring 2020 if conditions warrant and suggested the BoJ is thinking of keeping rates low for quite a long time. (Newswires)

Japanese Chief Government spokesman Suga says that PM Abe could dissolve the lower house of Parliament if opposition submits a motion of no confidence. (Newswires)

US Commerce Department place Huawei on their entity list, making the trade war more like a 'real' war. Trade talks have been stuck in a deep shock, Chinese are more convinced that concessions will not achieve peace, Chinese Global Times Editor. (Twitter)

 

PBoC will not let USD/CNY go above 7.00, according to sources. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

UK Labour leader Corbyn says that Brexit talks "have gone as far as they can", adding that he will oppose PM May's Brexit deal. Prior to this, UK Labour sources confirm that cross party talks with the government are definitely off, according to The Sun's Deputy Political Editor Hawkes. In addition Labour Party sources indicate that there is no point in doing a deal with a government which is on the verge of collapse. For reference, this does follow earlier reports that Labour are planning to pull out of cross party talks today, as according to sources. (Newswires/Twitter)

Prior to the Labour announcement it was reported that, cross-party Brexit talks will now move on to a second phase aimed at agreeing on a process for Parliamentary votes to find a Brexit consensus. (Newswires)

UK PM May and Labour leader Corbyn reportedly discussed plans to the leave the EU on July 31st and avoid a second referendum, according to Evening Standard citing a leaked document. (Evening Standard) Subsequently, a Labour source has stated that this document is genuine and has not yet been agreed by Labour.

- Aim being for Britain to leave the EU on July 31st

- Will be a separate free vote on whether to let the public have a final say, Whitehall source adds that the aim is to rule out a referendum before an exit plan is selected.

Italian Deputy PM Di Maio is not worried about potential EU sanctions against Italy as Europe will change after the European Parliamentary Elections. (Newswires)

EU HICP Final YY (Apr) 1.7% vs. Exp. 1.7% (Prev. 1.7%)

- EU HICP Final MM (Apr) 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.7% (Prev. 1.0%)

 

GEOPOLITICAL

Venezuela President Maduro alleged the US government has invaded Venezuela's embassy in Washington DC. (Newswires)

North Korea called UN an unfair organization and pledged to fight sanctions. (Yonhap)

Iran’s most prominent military leader has recently met Iraqi militias in Baghdad and told them to “prepare for proxy war”, according to The Guardian. (Guardian)

Iranian Revolutionary Guards say that even short-range missile can reach US warships in the Gulf. (Newswires) 

EQUITIES

A relatively downbeat session thus far for major European stocks [Eurostoxx 50 -0.5%], following on from a mixed lead in Asia where the Shanghai Composite shed 2.5% as hopes for a trade deal dwindled amid reports that China may not want to continue trade talks with the US for now. Major indices are broadly lower by around 0.5-0.7%, although, the FTSE 100 outperforms as UK exports benefit from the weaker Sterling. Sectors are showing broad-based losses with the exceptions of utilities (defensive sector) and energy names due to price action in the complex. Elsewhere, Thomas Cook (-24.8%) shares slumped for a second consecutive day, with traders citing the downside to a downgrade at Citi with a price target of zero. Finally, GVC Holdings (+2.5%) remain near the top of the Stoxx 600 after the Co. cut its potential impact from the FOBT GBP 2 limit from GBP 120mln to GBP 105mln. Notable pre-market US earnings this morning from Deere & Co (DE), who missed on EPS but beat on revenue and lowered their net income guidance.

 

Deere & Co (DE) Q1 19 (USD): EPS 3.52 (exp. 3.62), Revenue 11.3bln (exp. 10.19bln). Co. cuts FY 19 adj. Net income guidance to around USD 3.3bln (Prev. around USD 3.6bln) and revenue guidance to +5% (Prev. around +7%)

NVIDIA Corp (NVDA) Q1 19 (USD): EPS 0.88 (exp. 0.79), Revenue 2.2bln (exp. 2.2bln); sees Q2 revenue at 2.55bln (exp. 2.53bln); gaming revenue 1.05bln (down 39% YY). Co. shares rose 2% after-market. (Newswires)

 

FX

DXY - The Greenback has held onto the bulk of its post-US data/survey gains by virtue of advances against riskier/high beta counterparts as safer-havens within the G10 community are outperforming in wake of pretty defiant comments from China revealing a reluctance to pursue talks further given recent actions taken by the US. The index is hovering just below the 98.000 level after an apparent clean break of Fib resistance at 97.842 within a 97.953-759 range. To recap, 98.102 is the mtd DXY high and then the 2019 peak at 98.346 comes into focus.

JPY/CHF - As noted, the Yen and Franc are back in favour on US-China trade stains, but also as Brexit, Italian budget and geopolitical issues weigh on broad risk sentiment, with Usd/Jpy retreating from circa 110.00 highs back towards 109.50 and away from decent option expiries at the big figure (1.2 bn). Usd/Chf is holding around 1.0100, but Eur/Chf is back below 1.1300 and near recent lows not far from key chart supports and levels that may prompt some form of SNB action.

CAD/AUD/GBP - All on the back foot due to the aforementioned bearish/negative factors, as the Loonie revisits recent lows around 1.3500 and Aussie extends losses through 0.6900 to 0.6873 following latest jobs data that heightens the prospect of a June RBA rate cut after this month’s dovish hold. Similarly, the Pound continues to slide, and Cable has now hit fresh lows since the Valentine’s Day base of 1.2773 at 1.2755 on confirmation that cross party talks have come to a conclusion with no collusion in terms of an alternative WA. Note also, Gbp/Jpy has tripped stops on a break of the psychological 140.00 level.

EUR/NZD - Also victims of the ongoing Usd revival and overall downturn in risk appetite, with the single currency declining to fresh weekly lows and testing bids said to be sitting at 1.1160 and protecting 1.1150 ahead of the current 1.1135 May base, while the Kiwi is slipping further away from 0.6550 and closer to 0.6525 given only scant support from Aud/Nzd cross flows within 1.0550-25 parameters.

EM - Mixed blessings for the Turkish Lira as the US halved its tariff on steel, but removed preferential status on metals overall, while the AKP is still reportedly on a mission to tap CBRT reserves. Usd/Try extending above 6.0000 and testing resistance at 6.1000 before paring back, while the Yuan is not taking much heed of reports that 7.0000 is the PBoC’s line in the sand as the US-China tariff spat shows no sign of improving.

FIXED INCOME

Not a great deal of further action in bonds with Bunds capped and contained within a range by perkier core Eurozone inflation and a bit more strength at the Eurozone margins on the one hand vs another change in the tide of risk sentiment more broadly. However, UK debt and STIRs have recovered from their earlier Liffe wobble to edge fresh intraday highs (Gilts to 128.88, +27 ticks vs -1 tick at one stage) as the end of Tory-Labour talks becomes official and the 2 parties failed to find a common Brexit deal to put to Parliament. Meanwhile, US Treasures are holding a firm recovery bid after Thursday’s shake-out in the aftermath of healthy macro updates and a 3rd consecutive Wall Street bounce that may or may not extend given latest Chinese contentions on the trade situation with the US.

 

COMMODITIES

Choppy trade in the energy complex, although WTI (+1.1%) and Brent (+0.7%) futures are ultimately higher ahead of this week’s JMMC meeting in Saudi Arabia, which sets the stage for the OPEC/OPEC+ meeting in June. Focus will be on Iran’s situation amidst US sanctions and the expiry of waivers and whether there is scope to extend the current output cut deal between OPEC and its allies. Ship tracking data showed that Iranian oil shipments in May thus far has fallen to zero, however, ING highlights that a large number of Iranian tankers turn off their transponders. This follows reports of a tanker carrying Iranian oil reportedly unloading its cargo of almost 130k tonnes of oil near Zhousan, in China, Iran’s largest customer. Furthermore, comments from Iran’s revolutionary guard emphasis rising tensions between the country and the US, with the latest stating that “even short-range missiles can reach US warships in the Gulf”.

Market participants will be on the lookout for how US President Trump reacts to these threats from Iran. In terms of weekly price action so far, WTI futures are poised for a positive week after having breached its 50 WMA (61.81) to the upside whilst similarly, Brent futures are set for a week of gains, after having dipped below USD 70/bbl (and its 50 WMA at the figure) earlier in the week. Elsewhere, precious metals are little changed with spot gold (-0.2%) meandering further below the 1300/oz level after having lost more ground to yesterday’s rising Buck.

Turning to base metals, copper prices are back on the decline amid overnight news (reported via China’s state media) noting that China may have no interest in continuing trade talks for now amid little sincerity from US. The red metal is set to notch a 5th week of losses. On the flip side, Dalian iron ore prices continue their uptrend, up almost 10% this week amid robust demand and a number of supply side issues, including a warning from Vale that a dam at its Gong

To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

EQUITIES

A relatively downbeat session thus far for major European stocks [Eurostoxx 50 -0.5%], following on from a mixed lead in Asia where the Shanghai Composite shed 2.5% as hopes for a trade deal dwindled amid reports that China may not want to continue trade talks with the US for now. Major indices are broadly lower by around 0.5-0.7%, although, the FTSE 100 outperforms as UK exports benefit from the weaker Sterling. Sectors are showing broad-based losses with the exceptions of utilities (defensive sector) and energy names due to price action in the complex. In terms of movers, Just Eat (-7.2%) fell to the foot of the pan-Europe index following reports that Amazon are in talks to acquire a stake in Deliveroo for almost USD 600mln. Elsewhere, Thomas Cook (-23.7%) shares slumped for a second consecutive day, with traders citing the downside to a downgrade at Citi with a price target of zero. Finally, GVC Holdings (+2.5%) remain near the top of the Stoxx 600 after the Co. cut its potential impact from the FOBT GBP 2 limit from GBP 120mln to GBP 105mln.

FX

DXY The Greenback has held onto the bulk of its post-US data/survey gains by virtue of advances against riskier/high beta counterparts as safer-havens within the G10 community are outperforming in wake of pretty defiant comments from China revealing a reluctance to pursue talks further given recent actions taken by the US. The index is hovering just below the 98.000 level after an apparent clean break of Fib resistance at 97.842 within a 97.953-759 range. To recap, 98.102 is the mtd DXY high and then the 2019 peak at 98.346 comes into focus.

JPY/CHF As noted, the Yen and Franc are back in favour on US-China trade stains, but also as Brexit, Italian budget and geopolitical issues weigh on broad risk sentiment, with Usd/Jpy retreating from circa 110.00 highs back towards 109.50 and away from decent option expiries at the big figure (1.2 bn). Usd/Chf is holding around 1.0100, but Eur/Chf is back below 1.1300 and near recent lows not far from key chart supports and levels that may prompt some form of SNB action.

CAD/AUD/GBP All on the back foot due to the aforementioned bearish/negative factors, as the Loonie revisits recent lows around 1.3500 and Aussie extends losses through 0.6900 to 0.6873 following latest jobs data that heightens the prospect of a June RBA rate cut after this month’s dovish hold. Similarly, the Pound continues to slide, and Cable has now hit fresh lows since the Valentine’s Day base of 1.2773 at 1.2755 on confirmation that cross party talks have come to a conclusion with no collusion in terms of an alternative WA. Note also, Gbp/Jpy has tripped stops on a break of the psychological 140.00 level.

EUR/NZD Also victims of the ongoing Usd revival and overall downturn in risk appetite, with the single currency declining to fresh weekly lows and testing bids said to be sitting at 1.1160 and protecting 1.1150 ahead of the current 1.1135 May base, while the Kiwi is slipping further away from 0.6550 and closer to 0.6525 given only scant support from Aud/Nzd cross flows within 1.0550-25 parameters.

EM Mixed blessings for the Turkish Lira as the US halved its tariff on steel, but removed preferential status on metals overall, while the AKP is still reportedly on a mission to tap CBRT reserves. Usd/Try extending above 6.0000 and testing resistance at 6.1000 before paring back, while the Yuan is not taking much heed of reports that 7.0000 is the PBoC’s line in the sand as the US-China tariff spat shows no sign of improving.

FIXED INCOME

Not a great deal of further action in bonds with Bunds capped and contained within a range by perkier core Eurozone inflation and a bit more strength at the Eurozone margins on the one hand vs another change in the tide of risk sentiment more broadly. However, UK debt and STIRs have recovered from their earlier Liffe wobble to edge fresh intraday highs (Gilts to 128.88, +27 ticks vs -1 tick at one stage) as the end of Tory-Labour talks becomes official and the 2 parties failed to find a common Brexit deal to put to Parliament. Meanwhile, US Treasures are holding a firm recovery bid after Thursday’s shake-out in the aftermath of healthy macro updates and a 3rd consecutive Wall Street bounce that may or may not extend given latest Chinese contentions on the trade situation with the US.

COMMODITIES

Choppy trade in the energy complex, although WTI (+0.5%) and Brent (+0.7%) futures are ultimately higher ahead of this week’s JMMC meeting in Saudi Arabia, which sets the stage for the OPEC/OPEC+ meeting in June. Focus will be on Iran’s situation amidst US sanctions and the expiry of waivers and whether there is scope to extend the current output cut deal between OPEC and its allies. Ship tracking data showed that Iranian oil shipments in May thus far has fallen to zero, however, ING highlights that a large number of Iranian tankers turn off their transponders. This follows reports of a tanker carrying Iranian oil reportedly unloading its cargo of almost 130k tonnes of oil near Zhousan, in China, Iran’s largest customer. Furthermore, comments from Iran’s revolutionary guard emphasis rising tensions between the country and the US, with the latest stating that “even short-range missiles can reach US warships in the Gulf”.

Market participants will be on the lookout for how US President Trump reacts to these threats from Iran. In terms of weekly price action so far, WTI futures are poised for a positive week after having breached its 50 WMA (61.81) to the upside whilst similarly, Brent futures are set for a week of gains, after having dipped below USD 70/bbl (and its 50 WMA at the figure) earlier in the week. Elsewhere, precious metals are little changed with spot gold (Unch) meandering further below the 1300/oz level after having lost more ground to yesterday’s rising Buck.

Turning to base metals, copper prices are back on the decline amid overnight news (reported via China’s state media) noting that China may have no interest in continuing trade talks for now amid little sincerity from US. The red metal is set to notch a 5th week of losses. On the flip side, Dalian iron ore prices continue their uptrend, up almost 10% this week amid robust demand and a number of supply side issues, including a warning from Vale that a dam at its Gongo Soco mine risks rupturing

subject: Gilts and Short Sterling futures tentatively firm
content: The 10 year UK benchmark failed to derive much in the way of additional positive momentum after an initial mark-up to 128.77 from Thursday’s 128.61 Liffe close as follow-through buying stopped at 128.80 amidst another retreat in Bunds to a marginal new Eurex low at 166.86. Back to Gilts, the pull-back just breached parity by a tick and the early price action suggests Friday could be a day of consolidation following 4 yo-yo sessions in terms of overall sentiment on the fluctuating US-China and global trade machinations. In truth, trade and sentiment has been very erratic and volatile all week from the announcement of retaliatory Chinese tariffs and other countermeasures against the US on Monday, with recoveries in broad risk sentiment thwarted on Wednesday and again (partially) today. The latest reports are somewhat negative in terms of resolving the spate as state media indicate no willingness on the part of Beijing to resume talks soon, but on the flip-side sources intimate that the PBoC will intervene if the Cny hits the 7.0000 threshold vs the Usd. From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asia equity markets were mostly higher as the region took impetus from the positive performance on Wall St, where all major indices notched a 3rd consecutive win streak with risk sentiment underpinned by encouraging earnings from Walmart and Cisco. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.1%) traded positive with Australia led by continued strength in tech and amid the growing list of calls for a rate cut next month including notorious RBA watcher McCrann, while Japanese exporters were buoyed by recent favourable currency moves and as Sony shares surged over 10% after the announcement of a JPY 200bln share buyback. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.5%) were pressured after a lack of PBoC reverse repo operations throughout the week resulted to net weekly drain of CNY 50bln. In addition, China cancelled orders of 3247 tons of pork from US which was the largest cancellation in more than a year and was seen to be another fallout of the ongoing US-China trade dispute, while commentary in Chinese state media suggested China may have no interest in resuming trade discussions with the US for now.

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 17th May 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asian indices were predominantly positive following a firmer close on Wall St.; although markets were afflicted by negative US-China updates
  • China's state media reported that China potentially has no interest in furthering talks with the US right now; little sincerity seen by China in US President Trump’s approach
  • Cross-party talks between Conservatives and Labour are near to drawing to a close without an agreement; focus now turns to Parliamentary voting options
  • Looking ahead, highlights include EZ CPI (Final), US University of Michigan Sentiment, Fed's Clarida & Williams, BoJ's Kuroda & ECB's de Guindos
  • Earnings: Deere, easyJet

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets were mostly higher as the region took impetus from the positive performance on Wall St, where all major indices notched a 3rd consecutive win streak with risk sentiment underpinned by encouraging earnings from Walmart and Cisco. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.1%) traded positive with Australia led by continued strength in tech and amid the growing list of calls for a rate cut next month including notorious RBA watcher McCrann, while Japanese exporters were buoyed by recent favourable currency moves and as Sony shares surged over 10% after the announcement of a JPY 200bln share buyback. Hang Seng (-0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.5%) were pressured after a lack of PBoC reverse repo operations throughout the week resulted to net weekly drain of CNY 50bln. In addition, China cancelled orders of 3247 tons of pork from US which was the largest cancellation in more than a year and was seen to be another fallout of the ongoing US-China trade dispute, while commentary in Chinese state media suggested China may have no interest in resuming trade discussions with the US for now. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid the upbeat risk tone in Japan and on spill-over selling from the bear flattening stateside, while the BoJ’s Rinban announcement was for a reserved JPY 200bln of long to super-long JGBs.

 

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net weekly drain of CNY 50bln vs. last week's CNY 50bln net injection. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8859 (Prev. 6.8688)

 

China state media commentary said China may have no interest in continuing trade talks with the US for now and sees little sincerity in President Trump's approach. In related news, the NDRC said trade friction impact on Chinese economy is controllable, while it added that China is to study impact of tariffs and prop up growth when required.

 

BoJ Governor Kuroda said low rates must be maintained for a long period to achieve the price goal and that forward guidance is the framework in which BoJ will decide policy based on data and information available at the time. Furthermore, Kuroda said there is a good chance BoJ will keep current low rates past Spring 2020 if conditions warrant and suggested the BoJ is thinking of keeping rates low for quite a long time. (Newswires)

 

UK/EU

Cross-party talks between Conservatives and Labour are near to drawing to a close without an agreement according to the BBC. Talks will now move on to a second phase aimed at agreeing on a process for Parliamentary votes to find a Brexit consensus. There were separate reports that UK opposition Labour leader Corbyn is reportedly "inching" closer to getting behind a new Brexit referendum according to ITV. (BBC/ITV)

FX

 

The DXY held near the prior day’s highs after having found some support from stronger than expected US data, while its major counterparts failed to make any meaningful recovery from the prior day’s losses in which EUR/USD and GBP/USD gave up the 1.1200 and 1.2800 handles respectively with GBP/USD languishing at 3-month lows. USD/JPY attempted to surmount the 110.00 level on the back of USD strength and outflows to safe-haven JPY, where it eventually met resistance with the pullback aided by the pessimistic trade commentary in Chinese state media. Antipodeans were subdued in which AUD/USD traded sub-0.6900 after the prior day’s unemployment disappointment which spurred increased calls for the RBA to cut rates. As a reminder, Australia will head to the polls tomorrow to determine the country’s next PM with the opposition Labor party ahead across the opinion surveys on the back of a high-spending agenda including greater tax cuts, increased spending and a significant boost to the minimum wage.

 

White House issued notice on Turkey metal tariffs and said it is terminating preferential treatment of Turkey under Generalized System of Preferences effective on Friday, but also announced to lower ad valorem tariffs to 25% from 50% on steel imports from Turkey. (Newswires)

 

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed in which WTI crude futures marginally extended on the prior day’s gains above the USD 63.00/bbl level amid ongoing geopolitical risks and the predominantly positive global risk appetite. Elsewhere, gold languished after recent losses as the firmer greenback weighed across precious metals, while copper retreated overnight as sentiment in its largest buyer China soured amid ongoing trade uncertainty.

Production at oilfields that make North Sea Flotta crude grade has been shut down for repairs on a key pipeline, according to a spokesperson. (Newswires) 

GEOPOLITICS

US President Trump reportedly told Acting Defense Secretary Shanahan that he does not want to go to war with Iran. (NYT) Venezuela President Maduro alleged the US government has invaded Venezuela's embassy in Washington DC. (Newswires)

North Korea called UN an unfair organization and pledged to fight sanctions. (Yonhap)

 

Iran’s most prominent military leader has recently met Iraqi militias in Baghdad and told them to “prepare for proxy war”, according to The Guardian. (Guardian) 

US

At settlement, the curve had bear-flattened, though in early trade, there was a bid in the complex after news that Trump was going to take action on Huawei. The tough talk out of China’s MOFCOM also gave support to the complex in the European morning. However, after the European cash open, Treasury yields began to rise, and were booted higher further after a decent slate of US data. After that data, the drift has generally been horizontal. US T-note futures settled 8 ticks lower at 124-13+.

Fed’s Brainard (Voter, Dove) said the employment/inflation relationship has "broken down" and that weak inflation poses risks that households and businesses could set expectations in a way that makes it harder for the Fed to reach its inflation goal. Brainard also commented that low unemployment is helping the workers at the margin of the labour market, but low interest rates pose risks to financial markets. (Newswires)

Fed's Kashkari (Non-Voter, Dove) said wages are rising but not so fast to believe inflation will surge and rhetorically questioned why put the brakes on growth by raising rates but added that the Fed can always hike rates if wages start to rise too quickly. Furthermore, Kashkari said he would not prefer cutting rates as insurance and does not think it would do much for inflation expectations, while he thinks tariffs could boost inflation temporarily. (Newswires)

subject: ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia traded mostly higher after Wall St's 3-day win streak, although China lagged as trade uncertainty lingered
content: Asia equity markets were mostly higher as the region took impetus from the positive performance on Wall St, where all major indices notched a 3rd consecutive win streak with risk sentiment underpinned by encouraging earnings from Walmart and Cisco. ASX 200 (+0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.1%) traded positive with Australia led by continued strength in tech and amid the growing list of calls for a rate cut next month including notorious RBA watcher McCrann, while Japanese exporters were buoyed by recent favourable currency moves and as Sony shares surged over 10% after the announcement of a JPY 200bln share buyback. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.9%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.5%) were pressured after a lack of PBoC reverse repo operations throughout the week resulted to net weekly drain of CNY 50bln. In addition, China cancelled orders of 3247 tons of pork from US which was the largest cancellation in more than a year and was seen to be another fallout of the ongoing US-China trade dispute, while commentary in Chinese state media suggested China may have no interest in resuming trade discussions with the US for now. Finally, 10yr JGBs were lower amid the upbeat risk tone in Japan and on spill-over selling from the bear flattening stateside, while the BoJ’s Rinban announcement was for a reserved JPY 200bln of long to super-long JGBs.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia trades mostly higher after Wall St's 3-day win streak, although China lags on PBoC inaction and ongoing trade uncertainty
content:
Asia equity markets are mostly higher as the region takes impetus from the positive performance on Wall St, where all major indices notched a 3rd consecutive win streak as risk sentiment was underpinned by encouraging earnings from Walmart and Cisco. ASX 200 (+0.8%) and Nikkei 225 (+1.4%) are in the green with Australia led by continued strength in tech and amid the growing list of calls for a rate cut next month including notorious RBA watcher McCrann, while Japanese exporters are buoyed by favourable currency moves with Sony leading the advances after the announcement of a JPY 200bln share buyback. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.6%) and Shanghai Comp. (-1.2%) are cautious after a lack of PBoC reverse repo operations throughout the week resulted to net weekly drain of CNY 50bln, while there were also reports China cancelled orders of 3247 tons of pork from US which was the largest cancellation in more than a year and was seen to be another fallout of the ongoing US-China trade dispute.

In FX markets, the DXY holds near the prior day’s highs after finding some support from stronger than expected Philly Fed Business Index and US Housing data, while its major counterparts have failed to make any meaningful recovery from the prior day’s losses in which EUR/USD and GBP/USD gave up the 1.1200 and 1.2800 handles respectively. As such, GBP/USD languishes at 3-month lows amid the ongoing Brexit woes and PM May has vowed to set out a timetable for her departure and election of a new Tory leader after the vote on the withdrawal agreement bill early next month, while she is expected to resign regardless of the result of the WAB vote and former Foreign Minister Boris Johnson has confirmed his bid for the top job. Elsewhere, USD/JPY attempted to surmount the 110.00 level due to the USD-strength and outflows from safe-haven JPY, while antipodeans are subdued with AUD/USD trading sub-0.6900 after the prior day’s unemployment disappointment which has spurred increased calls for the RBA to cut rates. This includes NAB which brought forward its RBA rate cut projections to June and August from July and November and with WSJ's Glynn expecting the upcoming RBA minutes release, as well as a speech from Governor Lowe next week to set the backdrop for a cut as early as the next meeting. Furthermore, notorious RBA watcher McCrann was seemingly overzealous in a switch to the easing camp and now firmly believes a cut in the June meeting is locked in “no ifs, no buts and no probabilities”, although some have stuck to their guns on an August call including Morgan Stanley who suggested a cut in June is too early and that the recent jobs data is strong enough for the RBA to wait until August.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are lower amid the upbeat risk tone in Japan and on spill-over selling from the bear flattening stateside, while the BoJ’s Rinban announcement was for a reserved JPY 200bln of long to super-long JGBs.
